conclusion: The problem involves a hollow insulated cylinder with chambers of gaseous helium, and the task is to find the volume of the lower chamber when gas starts to leak.
The image shows a hollow insulated cylinder divided into two chambers by an insulating diaphragm, with both chambers filled with gaseous helium at pressure p and temperature T.
The cylinder has a height of 2H and a volume of 2V, with the diaphragm resting on a circular ledge and a gasket for tight contact.
A force is applied to the piston, causing it to move upwards slowly.
The total volume of the cylinder is 2V, which is divided equally between the two chambers initially.
Each chamber initially has a volume of V_0 = V.
The diaphragm is subject to an upward force due to the pressure difference between the two chambers.
The pressure difference is proportional to the mass of the diaphragm, the acceleration due to gravity, and the height of the cylinder.
When the gas starts to leak, the pressure in both chambers is equalized, and the diaphragm begins to move upward.
The upward force on the diaphragm is balanced by the pressure difference, which is given by mgH.
The initial volume of the lower chamber is given as V_0.
The gas leak begins when the pressure in both chambers becomes equal, and the diaphragm moves upward.
Using the given equation x = mgH/pV, we can equate it to the ratio of volumes: V_0/V.
Solving V_0/V = mgH/pV gives us V_0 = V (mgH/pV).
